title: 103_s1512
content: MENTAL ILLNESS RESEARCH, EDUCATION, AND CLINICAL CENTERS. The purpose of Sec. 7319 is to enhance healthcare services for veterans with mental illness through research, education, and improved delivery of mental health services by the Department of Veterans Affairs. The Secretary is authorized to implement these initiatives. The Secretary shall designate up to five health-care facilities as centers for research on mental health services, education, and training. These centers will focus on innovative clinical activities and systems of care. At least one facility must be designated by January 1, 1994, and the Secretary will ensure that the designated facilities meet the requirements for the centers. The Secretary for Health must ensure that designated facilities for research on mental health services are located in various geographic regions. The facilities must meet high scientific and clinical standards and have arrangements with accredited medical schools for education and training. The facility is affiliated with a school for education and training in psychiatry, psychology, nursing, and social work to provide students with training in the diagnosis and treatment of mental illness. The facility is affiliated with a school for education and training in psychiatry, psychology, nursing, and social work. It includes arrangements for personnel training in mental health care, attracting scientists for research, and a policymaking advisory committee. The facility is affiliated with a school for education and training in mental health care. The advisory committee advises on policy matters and evaluates activities to improve mental health services. An official in the Central Office of the Veterans Health Administration is responsible for mental health and behavioral advice. The Health Administration establishes a panel of experts to assess proposals for new mental health centers. The panel reviews and provides feedback on the scientific and clinical merit of each proposal. Funding for clinical and scientific investigations at each center is available through competitive awards. The Department of Veterans Affairs may fund mental health centers that prioritize projects related to mental illness. These centers must focus on improving care for veterans with mental illness through community-based alternatives. The Under Secretary for Health ensures that research findings are shared within the Veterans Health Administration. The Department of Veterans Affairs funds mental health centers for research and education activities. The official in charge supervises the operation of these centers. Appropriations are authorized for basic support of these activities, with specific amounts allocated for fiscal years 1994-1997. The Under Secretary for Health allocates funds from Department of Veterans Affairs accounts to support mental health centers for research and education activities. A clerical amendment is made to the table of sections in chapter 73 of the title. The Secretary of Veterans Affairs submits reports on mental illness research, education, and clinical centers to Congress annually. Reports detail activities, funding, advances in research, education, and clinical activities related to mental illness in veterans. The Under Secretary for Health disseminates information from mental illness research centers within the Veterans Health Administration. The Secretary evaluates the effectiveness of these centers in fulfilling their purposes. A technical amendment replaces "the Chief Medical Director" with "the Under Secretary for Health" in the relevant section of the title. Passed the Senate on March 24, 1994, attested by Walter J. Stewart, Secretary.
